entry.title: Japan Bank Charges in Payment Run
entry.content:
This blog post introduces the procedure of payments with the bank charges through a payment run in Contract Accounting. This solution is available for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

According to the contract, your contract partner, who provides the goods or services, covers the bank charges. This blog post introduces customizing activities and how they influence payment processing.

Master Data Settings

In the contract account level, you set up the cost allocation key and the instruction key.

  1. Open the contract account master date in the transaction CAA1 (Create) or transaction CAA2 (Edit).
  2. Based on the agreement between you and your contract partner, you can select the following instruction keys for Payment run:
    • D2 with bank charge: Bank charges covered by the contract partner
    • D1 without bank charge: Bank charges covered by the company
    • Leave the field empty if no bank charge is applied

Customizing Activities

Activating the business function – FICA_LOC_JP1

You must activate the business function to use the functions for Japan bank charges in Contract Accounting.

In the SFW5 transaction, double click the FICA_LOC_JP1 business function entry and activate it.

Activating Japan Bank Charge for Company Code

After you activated the business function in your system, you can switch on the Japan bank charges feature for specific company codes.

  1. Go to the Set Up Company Codes for Contract Accounts Receivable and Payable activity (view: TFK001B).
  2. Double click the entry of the company code.
  3. In the Country/Region-specific Functions select the Activate Settings for JP (Bank Charges) checkbox.

Activating Bank Charge for Document Type

In this activity, you activate bank charges for payment runs.

  1. Go to the Activate Bank Charges activity (view: V_TFK_JP_BCH).
  2. Enter the values for the payment run:

    Sample values:
    Application AreaCompany CodeHouse BankCurrencyDocument Origin
    C – Convergent FI-CA<Your Company Code><Your Company Code>JPY

    06 – Payment run

     

Determining accounts for bank charges

In this activity you post attributes assignment to include a tax determination for bank charge.

  1. In the transaction FQC0, enter 1111 in the posting area field and the Chart of accounts.
  2. Assign a G/L account and tax determination.

Defining Transfer Type for the Company Code and House Bank

In this activity you select a payment transfer type, such as domestic electronic bank transfer or domestic bank transfer by mail for the payment run.

  1. In the Parameters for DMEs and foreign payment transaction (view V_T012D_CORE), enter the company code and the house bank.
  2. In the Running Mode, you can decide how the payment is made.
    If you select the By Letter checkbox, the transfer type is domestic bank transfer by mail. Otherwise, the transfer type is domestic electronic bank transfer.
    Note: This checkbox selection is used in the following customizing activity – Bank charges determination (view: V_T042J).

Defining Bank Charges

In this activity, you can define amounts of bank charges for each set-up threshold based on the transfer types and bank types.

  1. In the Bank Charges Determination (view , enter the paying company code and the house bank.
    Note: This view is also used in Financial Accounting.
  2. You can define the threshold for bank charges based on the settings:
    • Bank type: Between the sender’s or the receiver’s bank the bank type can be (1) same bank and same branch, (2) same bank but different branches, or (3) different banks.
    • Transfer type: the transfer type must be consistent to the previous customizing activity. For example, if you select the By Letter checkbox, You cannot select other transfer type other than the domestic bank transfer by mail.
    • Currency: For bank charges, only the currency JPY is available.
    • From amount: set up the threshold from which the bank charge amount is applied. This threshold amount refers to the invoice amount plus VAT.

Assigning Payment Methods for Japan Bank Charges

In this activity assign the instruction key to the payment method used for Japan bank charges.

Open the transaction FQP1 at the Instruction key level you must assign the instruction key to the payment method used for JP Bank charges.
Maintain the Cost Allocation Key column to determine who pays the bank charges for the corresponding instruction key.

If bank charges are not required, the standard process is applied.

Procedure of Processing Payments

  1. You, as a company, post documents for outgoing payments with the invoice amount, for example, 5,000 JPY.
  2. Execute a payment run, that clears the paid open items
    Note: Only the payment method with direct clearing is supported.
  3. You generate payment file. In the payment medium file, the payment amount is already deducted by the bank charge. For example, if the bank charge is 215 JPY, the payment amount is 4,785 JPY. (See the payment file example below.)
  4. Send the payment file to the bank for the customer to arrange the payment.
  5. After transferring the payment based on the payment file, the bank sends you a bank statement file with realized payment of amount 4,785 JPY.
Example of Payment Medium Format with Bank Charges

Is this blog post useful to you? Leave your comments to let us know your thoughts.

entry.title: Re: Dunning per Mail/Printing only if there is no Mail-Ad...
entry.content: Hello @FabianSCC, Correct, you should not fill the Standard E-Mail Address column in your OPD table for this requirement. That filed is only used to force a fixed recipient, which from my understanding is not what you need. Instead, when maintaining the Channel step in the Output Parameter Determination app, use the Condition Fields dropdown and select Default E-Mail Address as your condition. Then build as previously mentioned two separate determination rules. The fallback should work correctly thereafter. Best regards Chris

entry.title: Re: Planned vs Unplanned Depreciation Behavior after Post...
entry.content:
Hi @archana_raut38 ,

Below is my inline response to your requirement.

Step/ScenarioWhat You DidSystem Behavior (Observed)Standard SAP Behavior (Cloud Public Edition)Recommendation
AcquisitionCreated asset with 100,000 acquisition, 10-year useful life, depreciation key LINSPlanned depreciation = 10,000/yearCorrect → LINS distributes depreciation automaticallyKeep depreciation key as LINS (or similar automatic key)
Unplanned DepreciationTried posting 20,000 unplanned depreciation. Changed depreciation key to Manual temporarilyAllowed posting, but automatic planned depreciation stoppedNot recommended. Manual key disables periodic depreciation in CloudDo not change key. Use “Post Unplanned Depreciation” app (or Post to Asset Journal) with LINS still active
Switch Back KeyAfter posting unplanned depreciation, switched back from Manual → LINSSystem throws error due to mismatchStandard check in Cloud: prevents inconsistent valuesKeep automatic depreciation key active from the start
Change Useful LifeAfter unplanned depreciation, reduced useful life from 10 → 8 yearsError occurred when combined with manual key switchNormally: Cloud recalculates automatically: Remaining NBV ÷ Remaining useful lifeFirst post unplanned depreciation, then adjust useful life. System spreads NBV accordingly
Client RequirementBoth: (a) Automatic periodic depreciation, and (b) Ability to post extraordinary depreciationNot possible when switching keysCloud supports both, but only when using correct apps (not key switching)Use automatic depreciation key (LINS) + supported Fiori apps for unplanned depreciation + change useful life after

Summary:
-What you observed is standard system behavior in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
-Do not switch depreciation keys.
-Always keep automatic key (e.g., LINS).
-Use Unplanned Depreciation Fiori apps to record extraordinary depreciation.
-Then adjust useful life → system will re-spread remaining NBV automatically.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback. Used GenAI
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: How to connect CPQ to Power Connect Tool?
entry.content:
According to documentation from Power Connect Tool, there is a possibility to integrate with CPQ, how is that possible from CPQ perspective?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to connect CPQ to Power Connect Tool?
entry.content:
Power Connect Tool allows to collect data from Events and User Audit Logs, monitoring health and operational activities. it requires API access using OAuth basic authentication flow to CPQ APIs.

In order to properly integrate, API username and password is needed - for that, you can create an user dedicated to this.
It is also needed to have your domain and tenant URL, both information are available at your environment Setup. Last needed information is Token URL, which consists in: https://{yourdomain}.cpq.cloud.sap/basic/api/token.

Other steps are done in Power Connect Tool itself, which can be reviewed in below URL:

https://help.powerconnect.io/powerconnectdocumentation/sap-cpq

entry.title: Building SaaS Products on SAP BTP
entry.content:
Building SaaS Products on SAP BTP

Disclaimer: This article was inspired by SAP's work on modern cloud development, particularly the blog "How SAP's ABAP Cloud Partner Reference App simplifies multi-tenant side-by-side extensions," and is intended to explore these critical architectural topics further.

SAP is undergoing its largest transformation in decades—moving from on-premise monoliths to cloud-native architecture. Products like Datasphere, Analytics Cloud, and Business Data Cloud exist only in the cloud. Yet despite this fundamental shift, most software vendors still treat SAP like it’s 2010.

Let me explain why this gap is a massive opportunity for disruption—and why mastering the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) is much harder than the marketing suggests.

The Architectural Divide: From Monolith to Node

To understand the BTP challenge, we must first recognize the dramatic shift in enterprise architecture.

The Old World: SAP as the Center of Gravity

For decades, SAP ECC was the undisputed heart of enterprise data. Every system pointed inward. CRM, warehouse management, custom applications—everything fed data into one central, tightly coupled system.

External Systems⟶SAP ECC Monolith⟶Single Source of Truth

This architecture made building SAP-integrated products deceptively straightforward:

  • Write ABAP code directly inside the SAP system.

  • Deploy via Transport Requests.

  • Access everything natively (tables, function modules, full transaction control).

I've seen incredibly sophisticated, high-performance solutions built entirely in ABAP. But notice this: many of these established ABAP vendors are slow to build cloud-native versions on BTP. This hesitation tells you something profound about the real challenges involved.

The New Reality: S/4HANA as Just Another Node

In today's distributed architecture, S/4HANA is simply one system among many. It sits alongside Salesforce, Workday, custom applications, and SAP’s own cloud products—all communicating through SAP BTP as the critical integration, extension, and application layer.

This fundamental change means you can no longer rely on deep, internal access to the core. It forces a complete overhaul of how you design and build SaaS products for the SAP ecosystem.

The BTP Reality: Why It's Harder Than It Looks

The core challenge lies in bridging the gap between the ABAP world's capabilities and the modern cloud platform’s constraints.

The ABAP Advantage (What You Lose)

When you build directly in ABAP (on-premise), you gain:

  • Direct access to all SAP objects and processes.

  • Standardized integration patterns (BAPIs, Function Modules).

  • Full transactional control and deep customization hooks.

  • 30+ years of accumulated frameworks and access methods.

The BTP Reality (What You Are Limited To)

On BTP, you are limited to officially sanctioned external access methods:

  1. APIs (REST, OData) – when they exist and are complete.

  2. RFC Calls/Web Services – (The "legacy" or "sidecar" approach).

  3. Custom ABAP Extensions – (The fallback when APIs fail).

The Technical Truth: Many older, niche, or newly migrated SAP modules do not have complete API coverage for every critical workflow step. This is not a criticism of SAP; it's the reality of a massive platform in transition. Building true SaaS products on BTP requires mapping your entire solution against the SAP API Business Hub before writing any code.

The Compelling Reason to Build SaaS on BTP

Despite the integration complexity, the strategic advantages of BTP are too significant for modern vendors to ignore. BTP is the enforcement mechanism for SAP's Clean Core strategy.

Strategic AdvantageWhy it Matters
1. Leverage SAP Objects Without Core ModificationUse SAP CAP (Cloud Application Programming Model) or RAP (ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model) to extend key SAP objects (Business Partners, Sales Orders, Materials) with custom fields and logic. This ensures your solution aligns with the Clean Core approach.
2. Instant User Management and SecurityIntegrate with BTP's XSUAA service. You instantly inherit customer's users, SSO integration, saving months of development and operational overhead on identity management.
3. Customer-Specific Extensions via MultitenancyShip one product while allowing customer-specific configurations and extensions. BTP's native multitenancy handles the data and configuration isolation, dramatically lowering codebase maintenance costs compared to the old world of branched ABAP code.
4. Modern Deployment and OperationsDeploy globally without hardware investment. Scale automatically based on demand. Use modern DevOps practices and CI/CD pipelines to update all customers simultaneously—a logistical nightmare with on-premise solutions.
 

Two Strategic Approaches to BTP SaaS

Your product's architecture should align with its core purpose:

Approach 1: Extend SAP Objects

Your product becomes a natural, value-add extension of core SAP functionality, leveraging the data models customers already use and understand.

  • Best for: Solutions that enhance existing SAP processes (advanced analytics, specialized compliance requirements, industry-specific workflows).

  • Technical Focus: Heavy reliance on CAP/RAP to extend standard entities and leverage the existing SAP transactional context.

Approach 2: Build Independent with SAP Integration (Loosely Coupled)

Create your own data model using modern frameworks (CAP/Node.js, Java) and integrate with SAP only as needed for master data and transactional exchange.

  • Best for: Products that could exist standalone but gain significant value from SAP integration (planning tools, specialized industry solutions, asset management).

  • Technical Focus: Strong emphasis on the SAP Integration Suite and Event Mesh for asynchronous, reliable communication.

The Common Pitfalls I've Observed

Architectural success on BTP is often defined by avoiding these common traps:

1. The API Gap Surprise

Teams design beautiful cloud-native architecture assuming APIs exist for everything. When they discover a critical workflow is missing an API, they are forced to write custom ABAP in the S/4HANA core to create a needed OData service.

  • The Lesson: This creates a Custom ABAP Sidecar—it defeats the purpose of the BTP-native, Clean Core approach for that use case, complicating deployment and creating system-specific dependencies. Map your integration requirements against actual API availability before committing to architecture.

2. The Custom Integration Trap

A company builds its first SAP integration for Customer A, which takes six months. Customer B has different middleware, a different S/4HANA version, and unique customizations. Three years later, the company has five customers but five completely different integrations with no reusable product.

  • The Lesson: Design for product reusability from day one. Use BTP as the standard integration hub for all customers. Your product should treat the S/4HANA backend as an interchangeable service, not a monolithic dependency.

3. The Deployment Complexity

The product itself might be excellent, but if every customer implementation requires weeks of external SAP consulting to set up roles, connect services, and configure the integration, the deployment model doesn't scale economically.

  • The Lesson: Design your solution to be simple. Aim for a solution that can be deployed and configured by the customer’s existing SAP team in days, not months, using automated scripts and minimal manual steps.

My Strategic Focus

My focus is clear: to master the architecture required to build and commercialize a CAP template SaaS solution. By leveraging the best practices of the Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) and designing for native multitenancy, I aim to provide a production-ready, clean-core blueprint that accelerates the time-to-market for modern SAP solutions. This is the strategic direction for dominating the next era of the SAP ecosystem.

entry.title: Re: Offboarding Reminder in Email Services - Are changes...
entry.content:
Hi @louis_oli4 

I believe these reminders will still send to those already terminated and sitting in Offboarding. However, it depends if those already terminated are not anymore active in the system - they will not receive emails anymore. It will only affect those you have triggered termination event but still active in the system. 

Keep in mind, Schedule OFB Meetings is an exception. This email can still send to the personal emails of the terminated employee. So if you will configure a reminder for this task. I believe it will still send.

entry.title: SAP Service and Asset Manager 2405 - MDK Metadata Deployment Error in SAP BAS Environment
entry.content:
Dear All,

I am currently in the advanced stage of the SAP Service and Asset Manager 2405 implementation and encountering an issue while deploying the SSAM metadata to SAP Mobile Services from SAP Business Application Studio (BAS).

The same metadata was successfully deployed to multiple Mobile Services landscapes approximately four weeks ago and application working fine. However, during the recent deployment attempt, I am facing an MDK validation error in SAP BAS, which is resulting in an incomplete or unsuccessful deployment. Notably, the same deployment process works as expected when executed from Visual Studio Code.

Validation Error:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[10:05:37] -- validating --
Start validating the application /home/user/projects/Dev/AA_Dev_Build_15_v1/SAM.mdkproject/metadata/ssam-metadata with the metadata schema supported in MDK SDK
node:internal/process/promises:392
new UnhandledPromiseRejection(reason);
^

UnhandledPromiseRejection: This error originated either by throwing inside of an async function without a catch block, or by rejecting a promise which was not handled with .catch(). The promise rejected with the reason "Validating the application /home/user/projects/Dev/AA_Dev_Build_15_v1/SAM.mdkproject/metadata/forms-ssam-integration-metadata failed with TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'file')".
at throwUnhandledRejectionsMode (node:internal/process/promises:392:7)
at processPromiseRejections (node:internal/process/promises:475:17)
at process.processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:106:32) {
code: 'ERR_UNHANDLED_REJECTION'
}

Node.js v22.13.1

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Upon analysis, I observed that the Node version in SAP BAS is v22.13.1, whereas in Visual Studio Code it is v20.4.0. Based on this observation, the Node version mismatch appears to be the likely root cause of the issue. From a code perspective, there are no changes or issues—this same custom metadata was last successfully deployed on 20th August across multiple landscape servers.

It is possible that SAP BAS was recently updated to a higher Node version (v22.13.1). Could you please confirm if there is an option to rollback or switch the Node version in SAP BAS to v20.x.x? I would like to attempt the deployment again using the earlier version to validate this hypothesis.

Any insights or recommendations on this would be appreciated.
Thank you in advance.

Regards
Venkata Pavan Vummadisetty

entry.title: Flagging a candidate that we do not wish to consider
entry.content:
We are looking for a way to flag a candidate that we do not wish to consider in the future.

We would like the flag/tag to be visible in the Candidate Profile, Applicant Workbench (currently on legacy), and to the right when viewing the candidate's application.

Only an elevated role should have access to flag the employee, but multiple roles in Recruiting should have access to view the flag.

Thank you in advance for your feedback!

entry.title: SII tip for Spain #5B: SII Adjustments for Canary Islands October 2025 - Enabling AIEM
entry.content:
With the upcoming legal change in the Canary Islands effective October 2025, SAP customers operating in Spain must ensure their systems are correctly configured to support AIEM (Arbitrio sobre Importaciones y Entregas de Mercancías). This blog outlines the necessary steps to enable AIEM in the tax procedure “0TXES” for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud or "TAXES" for SAP ECC.

The steps below provide a simplified overview of the required customizing. This is not intended to be a comprehensive implementation guide. For detailed configuration, please consult your SAP implementation partner.

Remark:  For SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the scope item 3SS is required. This will automatically update the tax procedure “0TXES” and does not require the manual steps defined in section 1. Nevertheles, section 2 will also be mandatory for public cloud. 

 

1. TAX PROCEDURE CREATION S/4HANA Private Cloud

1.1 Accounting key creation

Accounting keys can be created using transaction OBCN or via the following path:

SPRO → Financial Accounting → Financial Accounting Global Settings → Tax on Sales/Purchases → Basic Settings → Check and Change Settings for Tax Processing

You may create new keys from scratch or copy existing ones. For example:

  • Copy VST (Input Tax) → ZZI (or another name suitable for your business)

  • Copy MWS (Output Tax) → ZZO

 

Once created, press Save.

 

1.2 Calculation procedure adjustment

Navigate to:

SPRO → Financial Accounting → Financial Accounting Global Settings → Tax on Sales/Purchases → Basic Settings → Check Calculation Procedure

 

1.2.1 Define Condition types

Select the activity “Define Condition Types”.

Create new condition types for the accounting keys defined earlier:

  • ZZZI (Input Tax) as a copy of MWVS

 

  • ZZZO (Output Tax) as a copy of MWAS

Depending on your business requirements, you may choose different names or configure the condition types from scratch, adjusting fields such as “Control Data” and “Group Condition.”

Press Save.

 

1.2.1 Define Procedures

Select the activity “Define Procedures”.

Update the Spanish tax procedure with the new elements:

  • Select the tax procedure “TAXES” or "0TXES" depending on your system.

Note: Depending on your business needs, a different procedure may be required. Consult your implementation partner if unsure.

  • Add the new condition types and accounting keys:
    • Ensure step numbers are unique
    • The “From” field should reference the tax base amount line (typically 100)

 

Press Save.

1.3 Define Posting Keys and GL accounts

Define the posting keys and G/L accounts for the newly created accounting keys.

Use either:

  • Customizing path:

  SPRO → Financial Accounting → Financial Accounting Global Settings → Tax on Sales/Purchases → Posting → Define Tax Accounts

  • Or transaction SM34 with view cluster VC_T030K

Assign debit and credit posting keys (typically 40 and 50) and link them to the appropriate G/L accounts.

 

Selection of posting keys and accounts should align with your business requirements. Consult your implementation partner if needed.

Press Save.

 

2. CONFIGURE AIEM FOR CANARY ISLANDS

In case of S/4HANA public Cloud, use SSCUI 107186 “Assign Settings for Accounting Key Tax Type”. 

In case of S/4HANA private Cloud or ECC, use the following customizing path:

SPRO → Cross-Application Components → General Application Functions → eDocument → Country/Region-Specific Settings → Spain → Settings for Electronic IGIC Register Books With SII → Assign Settings for Accounting Key Tax Type. Alternatively, use transaction SM30 with table view EDOESCANTAXTYPEV.

Include the accounting keys created earlier (e.g., ZZI and ZZO) as AIEM-relevant transaction keys.

 

Press Save.

3. DISCLAIMER

This blog post is intended for informational purposes only and reflects a simplified configuration approach based on current legal and system understanding. It does not constitute legal or implementation advice. SAP system behavior may vary depending on version, scope, and customer-specific settings. For full compliance and implementation support, please consult your SAP implementation partner or legal advisor.

 

4. RELATED LINKS

In case of additional questions, you can refer to the official SAP documentation:

  • Electronic Tax Register Books with SII in S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • Electronic Tax Register Books with SII in S/4HANA Private Cloud
  • Electronic Tax Register Books with SII in ERP

Other SII tips and community discussions:

  • Spain – SAP Document and Reporting Compliance → Related Links → Community Section

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud 2508 / Error during the Migration of...
entry.content:
Hello @LukasKuhn 

Thank you for the follow-up.

The error Text ID 0002 is not valid for object KNA1 indicates that Text ID 0002 has not been assigned to KNA1, the Customer General Data object.

In S/4HANA Public Cloud, text IDs are dependent on objects.

KNA1 - General Data typically allows IDs like 0001 for general notes.

KNVV - Sales Area Data usually allows 0002 sales area notes.

That is why you encounter the error: you are attempting to post 0002 against KNA1.

Guidelines for possible resolution

For notes related to General Data, use KNA1 with a valid ID 0001.

If your note belongs to the Sales Area, switch to KNVV with Text ID = 0002 and ensure that Sales Organisation, Distribution Channel, and Division are filled in the template.

How to verify

In Maintain Business Partner → Customer:

Under General Data → Texts, you will see the valid KNA1 IDs.

Under Sales Area → Texts you will see the valid KNVV IDs, likely including 0002.

Since you’re already familiar with the system, I didn't include screenshots. I can send them if needed.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: MD01N Behavior: Provision Stock at Subcontractor Location Not Considered
entry.content:
We are encountering an issue with the MD01N transaction where it does not appear to recognize stock already provided to a subcontractor (supplier) for use in subcontracting orders.

The Problem: MD01N is generating additional purchase requisitions (PRs) for components that are already available at the subcontractor location.

Observed System Behavior: The system is not treating the provision stock that we have already supplied to the subcontractor as stock that is available for use (similar to unrestricted-use stock) within our main plant's MRP run. This leads to an incorrect demand calculation and the creation of unnecessary PRs.

Please note: We are not using subcontractor MRP areas to manage this stock.

 

Required Input: We need your input to help us understand and resolve this issue. Specifically, we need to identify the reason why MD01N does not treat the stock already available for a subcontractor as available/unrestricted-use stock within the plant's MRP calculation when subcontractor MRP areas are not in use.

Could you please provide guidance on the necessary configuration, master data settings, or potential solution that would allow MD01N to correctly consider the provision stock at the subcontractor location?

Please let us know if you require any additional information, such as specific material or plant details.

Thank you for your time and assistance.

 

 

Best regards,

Manohar.

entry.title: Tudo que você precisa saber sobre o SAP Cloud Availability
entry.content:
Esta é uma postagem traduzida. Consulte a versão original em inglês aqui. 

Estar bem informado sobre o status do seu sistema cloud e sobre os eventos futuros que possam ocorrer é crucial para o sucesso de qualquer organização empresarial nos dias de hoje. Pensando nisso, a SAP oferece o SAP Cloud Availability como um aplicativo que garante visibilidade e transparência de suas soluções cloud. 
 

 
Você pode estar se perguntando, como acesso esse recurso? Não se preocupe, vou guiá-lo neste processo.  

 
SAP Cloud Availability no SAP for Me  

O SAP Cloud Availability está integrado ao SAP for Me, que atualmente é o principal ponto de entrada para suporte na SAP.   
   
Para acessar o portal, é necessário um S-user ID, um identificador emitido abaixo das contas de clientes e parceiros da SAP, que oferece acesso às nossas principais plataformas de suporte, como o SAP for Me.   
   
Caso não esteja familiarizado com S-user IDs, recomendamos que confira nosso blog post para mais detalhes: Saiba como obter um S-user ID.   
  

Agora, veja como encontrar o SAP Cloud Availability:  

  1. Acesse me.sap.com utilizando seu S-user ID e senha.  
  2. Na sua página inicial, clique no painel "Sistemas e Disponibilização" na barra lateral direita.   
  3. Em seguida, navegue até a aba ‘Disponibilidade’ ou localize o cartão ‘Status de disponibilidade’ na aba de síntese.   
       

 

Configurando seu S-user ID 

Para acessar o SAP Cloud Availability, é essencial que seu S-user ID tenha pelo menos uma das seguintes autorizações: 

  • Exibir dados do Sistema (Display System Data) 
  • Editar dados do Sistema (Edit System Data) 

Caso ainda não possua essas permissões, entre em contato com o Super Administrador de sua empresa ou utilize o recurso de autosserviço para solicitar a autorização necessária. 

Identificando os administradores de sua empresa 
Para localizar os Super, Cloud ou User Administradores, utilize o aplicativo Usuários e Contatos. Acesse a aba "Meus contatos importantes" ou consulte o SAP Knowledge Base Article 3222501 para mais detalhes.    

Utilizando autosserviço para solicitação de autorizações 
Solicite suas autorizações indo a Minhas autorizações e funções. Clique na aba "Autorizações” e, em seguida, no botão “Solicitar autorização".    
 
Informações detalhadas podem ser encontradas no documento 2891528 ou no SAP Blog Post Como usar a solicitação de autorização de autosserviço.    

Explorando o SAP Cloud Availability   

O acesso ao SAP Cloud Availability permite uma visão completa de seus serviços e sistemas cloud SAP, abrangendo tanto ambientes produtivos quanto não produtivos. Os principais recursos incluem:  

  • Síntese de produtos cloud (verifique a lista de todos os produtos suportados nesta página).   
  • Status atual e histórico do sistema cloud.  
  • Eventos planejados.  
  • Últimas notificações.  
  • Relatório de disponibilidade comunicado. 

Ao acessar o aplicativo, o primeiro recurso que você verá será o cartão “Status de disponibilidade”.  
   
Ele fornece um resumo do status de seus sistemas cloud, identificando rapidamente sistemas indisponíveis ou permitindo que você filtre por soluções específicas.  


No canto superior de cada cartão estará o ícone de três pontos, que oferece explicações sobre o conteúdo, permissões necessárias e a opção de exportar os dados.   
 

 
Abaixo, você encontrará o cartão “Eventos”. Essa funcionalidade permite visualizar todos os eventos que impactaram seus sistemas nos últimos 12 meses. Ela inclui atividades planejadas e não planejadas, como manutenções, upgrades importantes e interrupções de serviço, entre outros.  
 
Você pode personalizar a exibição desses dados utilizando filtros ou a funcionalidade de expandir/comprimir os detalhes conforme suas preferências. 

O cartão “Availability Reporting” exibe a disponibilidade comunicada de seus serviços e sistemas Cloud ao longo do último ano.       
 

 
Todos esses detalhes podem ser facilmente monitorados e gerenciados diretamente no SAP for Me. No entanto, você também pode optar por receber notificações por e-mail sobre atualizações específicas, como falhas de sistema, upgrades planejados ou interrupções. 
 
Tudo o que você precisa é se inscrever para as notificações SAP Cloud. Consulte os SAP Knowledge Base Articles 2900069 e 2896942 para referência sobre como ativar essas notificações. 
 
Mais detalhes sobre o SAP Cloud Availability podem ser encontrados nos seguintes recursos: 

  • Disponibilidade Cloud no SAP for Me  
  • 2548400 - Introdução ao SAP Cloud Availability - SAP for Me  
       

Quem contatar para obter suporte?   

Se enfrentar problemas relacionados ao aplicativo SAP Cloud Availability, crie um caso de suporte com a equipe técnica do SAP for Me utilizando a funcionalidade “Obter suporte”.  
 
Certifique-se de selecionar ‘SAP for Me’ e ‘Systems & Provisioning > Availability’ nos campos relacionados ao produto para direcionar sua solicitação à equipe correta. 

Mais detalhes podem ser verificados em 1296527 - Como criar um caso de suporte para o suporte da SAP - SAP for Me.   

Além disso, você pode entrar em contato com o SAP Customer Interaction Center para suporte inicial ou orientação de navegação. Nossa equipe está disponível 24 horas por dia, 7 dias por semana, garantindo suporte ininterrupto, fornecido em mais de 10 idiomas.   
 
Para acessar as informações de contato, visite a página oficial do Customer Interaction Center no link: Contact Customer Interaction Center        
  
  

Agradecemos seu tempo nessa leitura! Esperamos que o conteúdo tenha sido útil e adoraríamos ouvir sua opinião. Conte-nos suas impressões!  
 
Fique atento aos nossos próximos webcasts de suporte e sessões gravadas para aprender a obter o melhor do suporte da SAP: Registre-se agora

 

Leia mais blog posts do #CustomerInteractionCenter aqui!

entry.title: How to handle varchar data that represents decimals in scientific notation: CI-DS
entry.content:
The input data is represented in a varchar field using scientific notation, for example '1.2000000000000000E+01'.

The goal is to transform that string into a number that CI-DS can use for math operations, such that:

  • 1.2000000000000000E+01 becomes 12.0
  • 1.2000000000000000E+03 becomes 1200.0

A direct mapping approach leads to the error: "Cannot convert data <1.2000000000000000E+01> into type <DECIMAL>."


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to handle varchar data that represents decimals i...
entry.content:
When CI-DS tries to implicitly convert a varchar to a decimal, encountering any alphabet character will interrupt the conversion of varchar data to decimal. As such, the E indicating an exponent for scientific notation causes issues for handling this data format.

 

To achieve the goal, you will have to combine some functions to parse the string and then perform the expected math operations. One possible approach:

  • cast(substr(<column name>, 0, index(<column name>, 'E', 1) - 1), 'decimal(18,6)') * power(10, cast(substr(<column name>, -2, 2), 'int'))

 

Slightly more readable:

  • cast(substr(<column name>, 0, index(<column name>, 'E', 1) - 1), 'decimal(18,6)') 
    *
    power(10, cast(substr(<column name>, -2, 2), 'int'))

 

What this mapping does:

  1. Identify the portion of the input number before the 'E' denoting the exponent. Cast that into decimal(18,6).
  2. Identify the exponent by pulling the last two characters with substr function. Cast that to an int.
  3. Raise 10 to the power of the identified exponent.
  4. Multiply that by the beginning portion of the decimal number.

entry.title: Re: line item empty SAP Fiori
entry.content:
HI @AnhThuc ,

AspectDetails
SymptomWhen using Upload General Journal Entries (and some other apps), no line items appear. Tax code field cannot be entered.
Possible Cause 1Authorization / Business Role issue – in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Fiori apps only show fields permitted by your business role(s). If you don’t have the role templates (e.g., SAP_BR_GL_ACCOUNTANT, SAP_BR_AP_ACCOUNTANT), some entry fields (like tax codes) may not appear.
Possible Cause 2App functionality limitation – The Upload General Journal Entries app (F2548) is designed for bulk journal uploads via Excel template. It does not support all line-item level fields interactively (e.g., tax code entry). Instead, you must: - Use the official Excel template (downloadable from the app), - Enter line items + tax code in the Excel, - Upload → system processes postings.
Possible Cause 3Missing related apps – For interactive entry with full field control (tax codes, cost objects, etc.), SAP provides “Post General Journal Entries” (F0717A) or “Post General Journal Entries – Advanced” (F0717B). These have full line-item input screens.
ConfirmationThis is not a bug. It’s expected behavior: Upload General Journal Entries ≠ manual journal entry app.
Resolution / Next Steps1. Check your assigned roles (ensure GL Accountant role). 2. If you need tax code entry: • Use Excel template in Upload General Journal Entries, or • Use Post General Journal Entries / Post G/L Journal Entries – Advanced apps. 3. If still missing, request your admin to assign the correct Fiori catalog (e.g., General Ledger – Journal Entry Processing).

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback. Used GenAI
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Grouping Multiple Dunning Letters into a Single Notice
entry.content:
Hi @Ayman101 

AspectStandard BehaviorLimitationPossible Options
Unit of DunningOne dunning notice is always generated per Business Partner (customer account).Cannot group multiple BPs into a single consolidated letter.–
Grouping within BPCan group items by company code, dunning area, dunning level, dunning procedure.Works only inside one BP, not across multiple BPs.–
By Accountant ClerkNot supported as a grouping dimension in dunning notice generation.Cannot produce one letter for all BPs managed by a clerk.–
Worklist ApproachUse Manage Dunning Proposals / Create Dunning Notices apps → filter by clerk to process all their BPs.Still creates one notice per BP.Improves processing efficiency but not consolidation.
Collections Management (scope item BFC)Provides worklists by collection specialist/accountant; allows consolidated communication options.Requires additional scope item; not part of all Cloud editions.Consider enabling if available in customer’s license.
Custom Output FormExtend dunning form template or adjust output parameter determination to merge notices.Limited in Public Cloud; may require partner development and strict testing.Could simulate “one letter per clerk.”
Manual ConsolidationExport generated notices and merge externally (PDF/Excel).Not automated, manual effort required.Workaround only.

Summary:
-In standard S/4HANA Cloud, dunning notices = 1 BP → 1 letter. Grouping by accountant clerk is not supported.
-Options are: Collections Management scope item, custom output form, or manual consolidation.

Divyesh

entry.title: Re: S4 HANA
entry.content:
Hi @manichemi1 ,

I am assuming the issue is in S4 Hana On-Prem version

Possible CauseExplanationHow to Fix (On-Premise IMG)
Ledger not assigned to company codeEvery company code must be assigned to at least one ledger (e.g., 0L = leading ledger).SPRO → Financial Accounting (New) → Financial Accounting Global Settings (New) → Ledgers → Ledger → Assign Accounting Principle to Ledger and Company Code
Missing accounting principle assignmentEach ledger must be linked to an accounting principle (e.g., IFRS, Local GAAP).Same customizing path as above → check accounting principle assignment.
Currency types missingUniversal Journal (ACDOCA) requires defined currency types per ledger.SPRO → Financial Accounting (New) → Financial Accounting Global Settings (New) → Ledgers → Ledger → Define Settings for Ledgers and Currency Types
Posting ledger mismatchYou tried posting to a ledger that is not active for that company code.Verify document posting ledger matches assigned ledgers.
Universal Journal integration incompleteThe ledger must be active in Universal Journal (ACDOCA) integration.SPRO → Financial Accounting (New) → Financial Accounting Global Settings (New) → Ledgers → Ledger → Define Settings for the Universal Journal
Field status conflictsWrong field status group may block postings.Check G/L master data → field status group alignment with ledger setup.

Summary:

-In On-Premise, the error almost always comes from ledger and accounting principle assignment.
-Make sure company code is assigned to 0L (leading ledger).
-Ensure accounting principle and currency types are correctly linked.
-Check Universal Journal settings in customizing.

entry.title: Re: mapping task in Magration object - Product
entry.content:
Hi @maggie2 ,

Below is the difference for both the options.

Aspect0001 – Take Value from Source/Staging Table0002 – Take Default Value
Source of the field valueComes from your migration file or staging table (legacy system data).Comes from SAP S/4HANA system default (pre-configured in customizing).
ControlYou have full control — each record can have a unique value.SAP decides the value — all records get the same default unless you change customizing.
When to useWhen legacy data has important variations (e.g., inspection type differs per material, customer, or asset).When legacy data is irrelevant or missing and you want SAP to assign a standard value.
Impact on migrationEnsures historical or specific legacy values are carried forward.Simplifies migration but may overwrite legacy variation, using default for all records.
FlexibilityHigh — each row in the source file can be different.Low — one default applies to all rows.
Example (Inspection Type)Material A → 01, Material B → 02 (taken from source file).All materials → 01 (SAP default) regardless of legacy values.

Key takeaway:

0001 = “Preserve legacy values.” Use when data matters.
0002 = “Let SAP decide.” Use when data can be defaulted.

entry.title: Re: No service found for namespace '', name 'API_OUTBOUND...
entry.content:
Hello @Kaito2 

Thank you for verifying the URL and your follow-up. If the path is correct, the next most common cause of this error in S/4HANA Public Cloud is an issue with the communication setup.

Can you confirm that the Outbound Delivery (A2X) service is assigned to an active Communication Arrangement? Only upon confirmation will the runtime service /API_OUTBOUND_DELIVERY_SRV;v=0002/ be exposed.

Make sure you authenticate with the communication user for Basic Auth or the OAuth client that is part of that arrangement. Using a business user with catalogue roles will not work for API calls.

For a preliminary assessment, attempt to access the Service URL → $metadata via your web browser

Note that for GET requests, X-CSRF-Token is not required; it is only needed for POST and PUT requests.

If $metadata still returns “No service found,” then the service is not yet active in the Communication Arrangement, and you will need to adjust that first.

Check the useful SAP Documentation below.

SAP Help – Communication Arrangements in Extend and Integrate Your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

SAP API Business Hub – Outbound Delivery (A2X)

SAP Note 1797736 – Gateway error log analysis

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Depreciation areas 92 and 93 not available for Sweden...
entry.content:
Hello @maekman 

The reason why Sweden appears different

In the Public Cloud, the Chart of Depreciation is provided per country and cannot be freely modified.

Finland’s content includes areas 92 (annual) and 93 difference between Book and Tax).

Sweden’s designated reporting areas are 01 (IFRS), 15 (Local Tax), and 32 (Local Book). By design, there are no equivalents to 92/93 for Sweden.

What you should do

Use the Swedish areas as delivered: 01, 15, 32.

If you need the Book versus Tax difference, calculate it in reporting by comparing 32 versus 15, for example, the CDS view, Analytical List Page, or standard asset reports

If you need annual figures, such as Finland’s 92, derive them from posted periodic depreciation and sum them by fiscal year. A separate section is not required.

If this is a legal requirement.

Since Public Cloud does not permit the creation of new depreciation areas, raise an SAP incident (FI-AA) if Swedish law or your auditor requires additional statutory areas beyond what SAP provides.

Below are useful SAP References

SAP Help Portal – Asset Accounting in S/4HANA Cloud

SAP Help Portal – Country/Region-Specific Features

SAP KBA 3344444 – S/4HANA Cloud: Fixed Chart of Depreciation content per country (publicly available)

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Sales rebate processing - condition contract pricing
entry.content:
Hello @KatjaWa,

Thanks for the suggestion. I tested this in Manage Condition Contracts – Sales Rebates within our S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition tenant.

As shown in the screenshot below, the system only provides the SAP-delivered condition contract types (0S01, 0S02, 0S03, 0S04, 0SG1, 0SG2, 0SG3, 0SG4 )

Although custom condition types can be created in SSCUI Define Condition Types, they do not appear here. This is intentional.

In the Public Cloud, condition contracts are limited to the pre-delivered rebate condition types.

Creating custom condition types or access sequences does not ensure their availability in the Manage Condition Contracts app.

If additional rebate condition logic is required, the correct process is to raise an SAP Influence Request or an incident to verify if it is included in the product roadmap.

SAP Help documentation

SAP Help – Sales Rebate Processing (Scope Item 1BQ)

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Cost Element Category
entry.content:
HI @piyush_kr ,

AspectDetails
Where maintainedIn the G/L Account Master Data (transaction FS00 on-premise or Fiori app Manage G/L Account Master Data in Public Cloud).
LevelChart of Accounts level (not at company code level).
WhyThe cost element category defines how postings flow into Controlling (CO) from FI. Since cost elements are integrated into G/L accounts, the assignment is done in the Chart of Accounts segment of the G/L account.
Examples- Category 01 = Primary Costs/Revenue - Category 11 = Secondary Costs (Activity Allocation) - Category 21 = Settlement
Controlling Area dependencyBecause it is at Chart of Accounts level, all company codes using that COA will inherit the same cost element category for the account.

Summary:
In S/4HANA, the Cost Element Category is maintained at the Chart of Accounts level within the G/L account master (not per company code).

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback. Used GenAI
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: REFX-IFRS16-Error-Closing balance 120,000.00 USD liab...
entry.content:
HI @cm_cm ,

AreaError / IssueRoot CauseChecks / Mandatory SettingsFix / Action
Message No. RECEPR503Closing balance 120,000.00 USD liability availableLiability balance already exists in clearing/valuation accountRun Display Balances for Valuation report; compare with contract expected valuesAdjust opening balances (FI posting) if not aligned
Message No. RECEPR505Difference 120,000.00 USD between clearing and contract valueContract valuation ≠ clearing account balanceReconcile liability account with valuation amountReset & rerun valuation after adjusting
Valuation ParametersContract value not matching simulationWrong valuation area/key date/methodIMG → RE → Valuation → Assign Valuation AreasCorrect valuation assignment, rerun valuation
Account DeterminationWrong account mapping for clearing/accrualClearing account differs from valuation accountIMG → RE → Valuation → Account DeterminationEnsure consistent accounts for accrual/deferral
Opening BalancesContract opening not posted or mismatch existsStarting balance differs from expected contract valueFI Opening Balance PostingPost/correct opening balances
Contract ConditionsCondition values inconsistent with valuationWrong rent/interest/charges setupRECN → Contract Master → ConditionsAlign conditions with valuation rule
Valuation RunOld valuation docs not resetSystem sees mismatch with prior postingsRECN → Valuation → ResetReset valuation and run new valuation

Summary:
The errors (503 & 505) both point to a mismatch between contract valuation and liability balance. Start with opening balance reconciliation, then check account determination and valuation parameters, and finally reset & rerun valuation.
